abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is unsatisfactory,
            sustainability unlikely, and the institutional development
            impact negligible. Lessons drawn from the project focus on:
            1) project design, outlining the need to distinguish
            "objectives" to be achieved, from
            "impacts" which should continue even after project
            implementation. In particular, the design of education
            projects should be realistic, in that education quality
            improvement requires substantial time to attain measurable
            impacts. Thus, the objectives of a short-time project, such
            as this operation, should have been stated in a simple,
            measurable, and attainable manner within the context of the
            country. Moreover, complex project design, and
            implementation arrangements should be matched to the
            implementing agency's capacity, or, systematic capacity
            development needs be built-in, as required by implementation
            demands. In addition, innovative projects require a
            realistic implementation timeframe, to allow effective
            adaptation to, or adoption of new methodologies; this
            project timeframe was too short for communities to adjust to
            new approaches. Project design, and allocation of funds, and
            time should look at attaining its development objectives,
            therefore, attention should have been given to high-impact
            qualitative inputs, i.e., teacher training, and
            instructional materials; and, 2) project implementation,
            whose arrangements need to be premised on country realities,
            backed by comprehensive capacity assessment, and, it is
            crucial that implementation readiness be developed at least,
            at the early stages of implementation. The need for
            Government commitment, and ownership is reinforced, to
            ensure collaboration in monitoring, and evaluation, funds
            allocation, management, and community mobilization.
